channel.title: VAST Research & Development on VAST | Visualization and Analysis Software and Technology
channel.description: Recent content in VAST Research & Development on VAST | Visualization and Analysis Software and Technology

item.title: Earth System Data Science
item.description: Term: 2020 - 2023 Website: https://ncar.github.io/esds/ NCAR’s Earth System Data Science (ESDS) initiative aims to build a community of technical support for geoscientists by addressing common big data challenges.

item.title: Project Raijin
item.description: Term: 2021 - 2024 Funding source: NSF Partners: NCAR/CGD, Penn State University, Colorado State University, Max-Planck-Institut für Meteorologie Website: https://raijin.ucar.edu/ The goal of this three-year NSF Earth Cube funded effort is to develop open source, Python based tools for the analysis of simulation data sampled on unstructured grids.

item.title: NCAR-SIA11Y
item.description: Term: 2019 - 2022 Funding source: UCAR, Smithsonian Institution Partners: NCAR, Smithsonian National Museum of African American History and Culture Website: coming soon Augmented Reality (AR) technology has been predominantly used to develop applications that visually augment physical spaces.

item.title: Project Pythia
item.description: Term: 2020 - 2023 Funding source: NSF Partners: NCAR, Unidata, and University at Albany Website: https://projectpythia.org/ With the support of a three-year NSF Earth Cube award, Project Pythia is a community-driven effort to develop the world’s goto resource for helping geoscientists at any stage of their career learn how to use the Scientific Python Ecosystem to support their data analysis needs.

item.title: SPERR Compression
item.description: Term: 2020 - 2023 Funding source: NSF Website: https://github.com/NCAR/SPERR SPERR is a lossy compressor for scientific data (2D or 3D floating-point data, mostly produced by numerical simulations).

item.title: VizAccess
item.description: Term: 2020 - 2021 Funding source: UCAR Presidents Strategic Innovation Fund 2020 Partners: NCAR Website: [coming soon] Accessibility of scientific visualizations for people who are blind/vision impaired (PBVI) is a critically underexplored area in visualization research.
